original.title: Bibimbap
original.description: Traditional Korean mixed rice bowl topped with sautéed vegetables, marinated beef, a fried egg, and spicy gochujang sauce.
instructions: Cook the short-grain rice and set aside.
Blanch spinach, drain, and season with salt, sesame oil, and garlic.
Sauté carrots, zucchini, mushrooms, and soybean sprouts separately, seasoning lightly with salt.
Mix beef with soy sauce, sesame oil, garlic, and a pinch of sugar, then stir-fry until browned.
Fry an egg sunny-side-up.
Assemble rice in bowls and arrange vegetables and beef on top.
Add the fried egg and serve with gochujang and sesame seeds.

original.title: Chicken Biryani
original.description: A fragrant layered rice dish cooked with marinated chicken and aromatic spices.
instructions: Rinse the basmati rice until the water runs clear, then soak it for 20 minutes.
Mix yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, cumin, biryani masala, and salt. Add chicken and marinate for at least 1 hour.
Boil the soaked rice until it is 70% cooked, then drain completely.
Heat oil in a large pot and layer half of the partially cooked rice at the bottom.
Spread the marinated chicken evenly over the rice layer, then cover with the remaining rice.
Sprinkle saffron milk and fried onions on top for aroma and color.
Cover tightly and cook on low heat for 30 minutes until the chicken is fully cooked and the rice is fluffy.

original.title: Bulgogi
original.description: Korean BBQ beef marinated in a sweet and savory sauce, then stir-fried or grilled to caramelized perfection.
instructions: Mix soy sauce, pear puree, sugar, garlic, sesame oil, black pepper, and sliced onions to make the marinade.
Marinate thinly sliced beef for at least 30 minutes (preferably 2 hours).
Stir-fry beef in a hot pan until browned and caramelized.
Serve with rice, lettuce wraps, or vegetables.

original.title: Butter Chicken
original.description: A rich and creamy Indian curry made with tender chicken simmered in a spiced tomato and butter sauce.
instructions: Combine yogurt, lemon juice, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, chili powder, garam masala, and salt in a bowl.
Add chicken pieces to the mixture and coat evenly. Cover and marinate for at least 1 hour to absorb flavors.
Heat 2 tablespoons of butter in a pan and cook the marinated chicken until lightly browned on all sides. Remove and set aside.
In the same pan, add the remaining butter and pour in the tomato puree. Let it cook for 10 minutes until slightly thickened.
Add the chicken back into the sauce and simmer on low heat for 15 minutes so the flavors blend well.
Pour in the heavy cream and stir until the sauce becomes rich and creamy. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Taste and adjust salt or spices if needed before serving.

original.title: Chana Masala
original.description: A hearty chickpea curry cooked with tomatoes, onions, and aromatic Indian spices.
instructions: Heat oil in a pot and add cumin seeds. Let them crackle to release their aroma.
Add chopped onions and sauté until soft and lightly golden.
Stir in ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes, turmeric, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the tomatoes break down into a thick sauce.
Add the cooked chickpeas and mix well to coat them with the masala paste.
Pour in 1 cup of water and bring to a gentle boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes.
Stir in garam masala, cook for 2 more minutes, and adjust seasoning if needed.

original.title: Chicken Pastilla (B'stilla)
original.description: An elaborate sweet and savory pie with spiced chicken, almonds, and eggs wrapped in delicate warqa pastry, dusted with cinnamon and sugar.
instructions: Place chicken in large pot with onions, parsley, cilantro, spices (1 tbsp cinnamon, ginger, turmeric, saffron, salt, pepper), and cover with water. Bring to boil, then simmer for 1.5 hours until chicken is very tender.
Remove chicken, let cool, then shred meat, discarding skin and bones. Strain and reserve cooking liquid.
Toast almonds in dry pan until golden, then coarsely chop. Mix with 50g sugar and 1 tbsp orange blossom water.
In a clean pan, reduce 2 cups of reserved cooking liquid by half. Beat eggs and slowly pour into reduced liquid, stirring constantly to make a thick custard. Cook until set but still moist.
Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Brush a round baking dish with melted butter.
Layer 10 sheets of warqa/phyllo in the dish, brushing each sheet generously with melted butter and rotating sheets to cover entire dish with overhang.
Spread shredded chicken evenly over pastry. Top with egg custard, then almond mixture.
Fold overhanging pastry over filling. Cover with remaining 10 pastry sheets, brushing each with butter.
Tuck edges neatly and brush top with remaining butter. Bake for 30-40 minutes until golden and crisp.
Remove from oven and immediately invert onto serving platter so the bottom becomes the top.
Dust generously with powdered sugar and decorate with cinnamon lines in a lattice pattern.
Serve warm, cutting into wedges to show the beautiful layers.

original.title: Chicken Tacos
original.description: Classic Mexican tacos with grilled chicken, cilantro, lime, and onions.
instructions: Wash and pat dry the chicken breast.
Season both sides with salt, pepper, cumin, and paprika.
Heat a skillet over medium heat and add oil.
Cook the chicken for 5-7 minutes per side until fully cooked.
Remove chicken and let it rest for 5 minutes.
Slice or shred the chicken into pieces.
Warm tortillas on a dry skillet for 30-60 seconds per side.
Place chicken on tortillas, top with onion and cilantro.
Squeeze lime juice over the tacos and serve.

original.title: Chicken Tagine with Preserved Lemon and Olives
original.description: The iconic Moroccan slow-cooked stew featuring tender chicken in an aromatic broth with preserved lemons, olives, and traditional spices.
instructions: In a small bowl, crush saffron threads and soak in 1/4 cup warm water.
Rinse preserved lemons, scrape out pulp, and cut rind into strips. Set aside.
In a large tagine or heavy pot, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and cook until soft and translucent, about 10 minutes.
Add minced garlic and grated fresh ginger, cook for 2 more minutes.
Add chicken pieces skin-side down and brown on all sides, about 10 minutes total.
Add all ground spices (ginger, cumin, paprika, turmeric, black pepper, salt) and soaked saffron with its water. Stir well to coat chicken.
Add chopped cilantro and parsley, reserving some for garnish.
Pour in 500ml water and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 45 minutes.
After 45 minutes, add preserved lemon rinds and green olives. Continue cooking for another 30 minutes until chicken is very tender and falling off the bone.
Stir in lemon juice and adjust seasoning if needed. The sauce should be rich and slightly reduced.
Garnish with remaining fresh herbs and serve directly from the tagine with crusty bread or couscous.

original.title: Moroccan Couscous with Seven Vegetables
original.description: The national dish of Morocco - fluffy steamed couscous served with a rich vegetable and meat stew, traditionally prepared on Fridays.

ingredients.item: Lamb or beef, cut into chunks
Carrots, peeled and cut into chunks
Pumpkin or squash, cut into chunks
Fresh cilantro, tied in a bundle
Fresh parsley, tied in a bundle

instructions: Soak saffron in 1/4 cup warm water. Drain soaked chickpeas.
In the base of a couscoussier or large pot, heat olive oil. Brown meat on all sides.
Add onions and cook until soft. Add grated tomatoes, tomato paste, and all spices (ginger, turmeric, saffron water, pepper, 1 tbsp salt). Cook for 5 minutes.
Add 2.5L water, cilantro and parsley bundles, and bring to boil. Skim foam, then reduce heat and simmer for 45 minutes.
Add chickpeas and hard vegetables (carrots, turnips). Simmer for 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, prepare couscous: Place dry couscous in a large bowl. Mix 1 tbsp salt with 500ml warm water and gradually sprinkle over couscous, tossing with fingers to distribute evenly. Let rest 10 minutes.
Add remaining vegetables (zucchini, cabbage, pumpkin) to stew. Cook for 15 minutes.
Place couscous in top of couscoussier over simmering stew. Steam for 15 minutes.
Remove couscous to large bowl. Break up lumps with fork or hands. Sprinkle with 250ml cold water and 50g butter, working with fingers to separate grains.
Return couscous to steamer and steam for another 15 minutes over the stew.
Remove herbs bundles from stew. Adjust seasoning of broth.
To serve: Mound couscous on large platter, making a well in center. Arrange meat and vegetables over and around couscous.
Moisten with some broth and dot with remaining butter. Serve remaining broth and harissa separately for individuals to add to taste.

searchable.tags_text: national dish vegetables steamed friday traditional
searchable.full_text: Moroccan Couscous with Seven Vegetables The national dish of Morocco - fluffy steamed couscous served with a rich vegetable and meat stew, traditionally prepared on Fridays. Lamb or beef, cut into chunks 1kg Couscous 500g Onions, chopped 2 large Tomatoes, grated 3 Tomato paste 2 tbsp Carrots, peeled and cut into chunks 4 Zucchini, cut into chunks 3 Turnips, peeled and quartered 2 Cabbage, cut into wedges 1/4 Pumpkin or squash, cut into chunks 300g Chickpeas, soaked overnight 200g Fresh cilantro, tied in a bundle 1 bunch Fresh parsley, tied in a bundle 1 bunch Ground ginger 2 tsp Turmeric 1 tbsp Saffron threads 1/2 tsp Black pepper 1 tsp Salt 2 tbsp Butter 100g Olive oil 4 tbsp Water 2.5L Harissa sauce for serving to taste Soak saffron in 1/4 cup warm water. Drain soaked chickpeas. In the base of a couscoussier or large pot, heat olive oil. Brown meat on all sides. Add onions and cook until soft. Add grated tomatoes, tomato paste, and all spices (ginger, turmeric, saffron water, pepper, 1 tbsp salt). Cook for 5 minutes. Add 2.5L water, cilantro and parsley bundles, and bring to boil. Skim foam, then reduce heat and simmer for 45 minutes. Add chickpeas and hard vegetables (carrots, turnips). Simmer for 30 minutes. Meanwhile, prepare couscous: Place dry couscous in a large bowl. Mix 1 tbsp salt with 500ml warm water and gradually sprinkle over couscous, tossing with fingers to distribute evenly. Let rest 10 minutes. Add remaining vegetables (zucchini, cabbage, pumpkin) to stew. Cook for 15 minutes. Place couscous in top of couscoussier over simmering stew. Steam for 15 minutes. Remove couscous to large bowl. Break up lumps with fork or hands. Sprinkle with 250ml cold water and 50g butter, working with fingers to separate grains. Return couscous to steamer and steam for another 15 minutes over the stew. Remove herbs bundles from stew. Adjust seasoning of broth. To serve: Mound couscous on large platter, making a well in center. Arrange meat and vegetables over and around couscous. Moisten with some broth and dot with remaining butter. Serve remaining broth and harissa separately for individuals to add to taste. national dish vegetables steamed friday traditional

original.title: Gołąbki (Polish Stuffed Cabbage Rolls)
original.description: Tender cabbage leaves stuffed with a savory mixture of meat and rice, baked in a rich tomato sauce - a beloved Polish family dish.
instructions: Bring large pot of water to boil. Core cabbage and place whole in boiling water. Cook for 10-15 minutes until leaves soften.
Carefully remove leaves as they loosen. Trim thick ribs from leaves. Set aside 12-16 large leaves.
Cook rice according to package but reduce cooking time by 5 minutes (it will finish cooking in oven).
In skillet, melt butter and sauté onions until translucent, about 8 minutes. Add garlic and cook 1 minute more.
In large bowl, mix ground meats, partially cooked rice, sautéed onions/garlic, egg, marjoram, paprika, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp pepper, dill and parsley.
Place about 1/3 cup filling on each cabbage leaf. Fold sides over filling, then roll up tightly.
Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Arrange cabbage rolls seam-side down in large baking dish.
For sauce: Whisk tomato sauce, tomato paste, beef broth, flour, brown sugar, remaining salt and pepper.
Pour sauce over cabbage rolls, adding bay leaves. Cover tightly with foil.
Bake for 1.5 hours. Remove foil and bake 30 minutes more until sauce is bubbly and slightly thickened.
Let rest 15 minutes before serving. Serve with sour cream and crusty bread to soak up sauce.

original.title: Jawhara (Moroccan Orange and Almond Cake)
original.description: An exquisite, moist almond cake soaked in orange syrup, known for its luxurious texture and vibrant citrus flavor.
instructions: Wash oranges thoroughly. Place whole oranges in a pot, cover with water, and boil for 2 hours until very soft. Drain and let cool completely.
Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease and line a 9-inch round cake pan with parchment paper.
Cut cooled oranges into quarters, remove any seeds, then blend entire oranges (skin and all) into a smooth puree.
In a large bowl, whisk together ground almonds, semolina, flour, baking powder, and salt.
In another bowl, beat eggs with sugar until pale and thick. Gradually add oil while continuing to beat.
Add orange puree and 2 tbsp orange blossom water to egg mixture, mixing well.
Gradually fold dry ingredients into wet ingredients until just combined. Do not overmix.
Pour batter into prepared pan and bake for 45-55 minutes, or until a skewer comes out clean.

While cake bakes, make syrup: Combine 200g sugar, 250ml water, and lemon juice in a saucepan. Bring to boil, then simmer for 10 minutes until slightly thickened. Remove from heat and stir in 1 tbsp orange blossom water.
As soon as cake comes out of oven, pour hot syrup evenly over the hot cake. Let cake cool completely in the pan.
Garnish with toasted almond flakes and orange zest before serving.

original.title: Kibbeh
original.description: A traditional Syrian dish made with a mixture of fine bulgur, minced meat, and spices, shaped into ovals and stuffed before frying.
instructions: Soak fine bulgur in warm water for 20 minutes, then drain well.
Mix the bulgur with half of the minced meat, onion, salt, pepper, cumin, and cinnamon. Blend or knead until a smooth dough forms.
Prepare stuffing: sauté the remaining minced meat with onions, spices, and optional pine nuts.
Shape kibbeh into oval shells and fill them with the cooked meat mixture.
Fry in hot oil until golden brown and crispy.

original.title: Pizza Margherita
original.description: The classic Neapolitan pizza with a thin, chewy crust, simple tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella, and basil representing the Italian flag.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm water. In a large bowl, mix flour and salt. Make a well and pour in yeast mixture.
Mix until a shaggy dough forms, then knead on floured surface for 10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Place dough in oiled bowl, cover, and let rise for 8-24 hours in refrigerator for slow fermentation.
Remove dough 2 hours before baking. Divide into 3 balls, cover, and let rest.
For sauce: Crush San Marzano tomatoes by hand. Mix with minced garlic, 1 tbsp olive oil, salt, and pepper.
Preheat oven with pizza stone to maximum temperature (280-300°C/535-575°F) for at least 1 hour.
Stretch dough balls into 12-inch circles on semolina-dusted surface. Don't use rolling pin.
Spread thin layer of tomato sauce, leaving 1-inch border. Tear mozzarella into pieces and distribute.
Drizzle with olive oil and slide onto hot pizza stone. Bake for 60-90 seconds until crust is puffed and charred in spots.
Remove from oven, top with fresh basil leaves, another drizzle of olive oil, and serve immediately.

searchable.title: Pizza Margherita
searchable.description: The classic Neapolitan pizza with a thin, chewy crust, simple tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella, and basil representing the Italian flag.
searchable.ingredients_text: Type 00 flour 500g Warm water 325ml Fresh yeast 3g Sea salt 10g San Marzano tomatoes 400g Fresh mozzarella di bufala 250g Fresh basil leaves 20 Extra virgin olive oil 3 tbsp Garlic clove 1 Salt 1 tsp Black pepper 1/2 tsp Semolina flour for dusting
searchable.instructions_text: Dissolve yeast in warm water. In a large bowl, mix flour and salt. Make a well and pour in yeast mixture. Mix until a shaggy dough forms, then knead on floured surface for 10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Place dough in oiled bowl, cover, and let rise for 8-24 hours in refrigerator for slow fermentation. Remove dough 2 hours before baking. Divide into 3 balls, cover, and let rest. For sauce: Crush San Marzano tomatoes by hand. Mix with minced garlic, 1 tbsp olive oil, salt, and pepper. Preheat oven with pizza stone to maximum temperature (280-300°C/535-575°F) for at least 1 hour. Stretch dough balls into 12-inch circles on semolina-dusted surface. Don't use rolling pin. Spread thin layer of tomato sauce, leaving 1-inch border. Tear mozzarella into pieces and distribute. Drizzle with olive oil and slide onto hot pizza stone. Bake for 60-90 seconds until crust is puffed and charred in spots. Remove from oven, top with fresh basil leaves, another drizzle of olive oil, and serve immediately.

original.title: Masala Dosa
original.description: A crispy South Indian rice crepe filled with a spiced potato mixture.
instructions: Heat oil in a wide pan and add mustard seeds. When they begin to splutter, add curry leaves and green chilies.
Add sliced onions and sauté until translucent and soft.
Crumble the boiled potatoes and add them to the pan along with turmeric and salt.
Mix everything well and cook for 5 minutes until the flavors blend, then set the potato filling aside.
Heat a flat pan or tawa on medium heat. Pour a ladle of dosa batter and spread it thinly in a circular motion.
Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges and cook until the dosa becomes golden and crisp.
Place a spoonful of potato filling in the center, fold the dosa, and serve hot.

original.title: Mazurek (Polish Easter Cake)
original.description: A traditional flat cake with shortbread base and decorative sweet toppings, intricately decorated for Easter celebrations.

ingredients.item: For fruit topping: Mixed dried fruits

instructions: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease 9x13 inch baking pan or traditional mazurek pan.
For dough: In food processor, pulse flour, powdered sugar, and salt. Add cold butter and pulse until crumbly.
Add egg yolks, sour cream, and vanilla. Pulse until dough comes together. Don't overmix.
Press dough evenly into prepared pan. Prick all over with fork. Bake for 20-25 minutes until light golden. Cool completely.
For almond topping: Beat egg whites until foamy. Gradually add sugar and beat until stiff peaks. Fold in ground almonds and lemon juice. Spread over cooled crust.
For fruit topping: Warm apricot jam with 2 tbsp water. Spread thin layer over crust. Arrange dried fruits and candied peel in decorative patterns. Brush with remaining jam.
For chocolate topping: Heat cream until steaming. Pour over chopped chocolate, let sit 5 minutes, then stir until smooth. Add butter and stir until glossy. Spread over crust.
Bake almond-topped mazurek for 15-20 minutes until golden. Fruit and chocolate versions don't need baking.
Cool completely in pan. Create intricate designs using different toppings in sections or make one unified design.
Use nuts, candied fruits, or piped chocolate to create Easter motifs: lambs, crosses, flowers, or geometric patterns.
Let set completely (refrigerate chocolate version). Cut into small squares or diamonds while still in pan.
Dust with powdered sugar before serving. Mazurek should be very sweet and rich - serve small portions.

original.title: Mhalabia
original.description: A light Syrian milk pudding flavored with orange blossom water and topped with crushed pistachios.
instructions: Heat milk in a saucepan over medium heat.
Dissolve cornstarch in a small amount of cold milk and add it to the pot.
Add sugar and stir continuously until thickened.
Remove from heat and add orange blossom water.
Pour into cups and garnish with pistachios.

original.title: Miso Soup
original.description: A traditional Japanese soup made with dashi broth, miso paste, tofu cubes, and wakame seaweed.
instructions: Heat the dashi broth in a pot over medium heat until it becomes hot but not boiling. Avoid boiling to preserve the delicate flavors.
Soak the dried wakame seaweed in a small bowl of water for 5 minutes, then drain and set aside.
Cut the tofu into small, even cubes of about 1 cm for a traditional texture.
Place the wakame and tofu into the hot dashi broth and simmer gently for 2–3 minutes.
In a small separate bowl, add the miso paste. Ladle a small amount of the hot broth into the bowl and whisk until the miso dissolves completely.
Turn off the heat under the soup pot. Stir in the dissolved miso mixture gently to avoid lumps.
Add the chopped green onions right before serving for a fresh flavor.
Serve immediately while warm, as miso soup should not be reheated to boiling.

original.title: Risotto ai Funghi Porcini
original.description: Creamy Arborio rice cooked slowly with broth, white wine, and dried porcini mushrooms, finished with Parmesan and butter.
instructions: Soak dried porcini in 2 cups warm water for 30 minutes. Remove mushrooms, strain liquid through cheesecloth, and add to broth.
Heat broth with bay leaf in separate pot and keep at gentle simmer.
Clean and slice fresh mushrooms. Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in large pan, sauté fresh mushrooms until golden. Set aside.
In heavy-bottomed pot, melt 2 tbsp butter with 1 tbsp olive oil. Cook onion until soft and translucent, about 8 minutes.
Add rice and toast for 2 minutes until grains are hot and slightly translucent at edges.
Add white wine and stir until completely absorbed.
Add soaked porcini mushrooms. Begin adding hot broth one ladle at a time, stirring constantly.
Wait until each addition is almost absorbed before adding next ladle. Continue for 18-20 minutes.
After 15 minutes, add sautéed fresh mushrooms. Continue adding broth until rice is al dente and creamy.
Remove from heat. Stir in remaining butter and Parmigiano-Reggiano vigorously (mantecatura).
Cover and let rest for 2 minutes. Adjust seasoning, stir in parsley, and serve immediately.

original.title: Okonomiyaki
original.description: A savory Japanese pancake filled with cabbage and topped with flavorful sauces.
instructions: Mix flour, water, and eggs in a bowl until the batter is smooth.
Fold in the shredded cabbage and chopped green onions until they are evenly coated in the mixture.
Heat oil in a large pan over medium heat. Pour in one portion of batter and shape it into a thick pancake.
Cook for 4–5 minutes until the bottom is golden and firm, then flip carefully using a spatula.
Cook the other side for another 4 minutes, pressing lightly to help it cook evenly.
Transfer to a plate and drizzle with okonomiyaki sauce and mayonnaise in zigzag patterns before serving.

original.title: Palak Paneer
original.description: A creamy spinach curry cooked with soft paneer cubes and aromatic spices.
instructions: Blanch the spinach by boiling it for 2 minutes, then immediately transferring it to ice water to keep the color vibrant.
Blend the spinach and green chili into a smooth puree and set aside.
Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds. Once they sizzle, add chopped onions.
Cook the onions until golden, then add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute.
Pour in the spinach puree and cook for 5 minutes on medium heat to thicken the sauce.
Add paneer cubes and gently stir so they absorb the spinach flavors.
Finish by adding cream, salt, and simmering for another 3 minutes.

original.title: Pierogi Ruskie (Polish Dumplings)
original.description: Classic Polish dumplings with a savory filling of potatoes, farmer's cheese, and onions, boiled to perfection and served with fried onions and sour cream.
instructions: For dough: In a large bowl, mix flour and salt. Make a well and add egg, oil, and warm water. Mix until shaggy dough forms.
Knead on floured surface for 8-10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover with bowl and rest for 30 minutes.
For filling: Peel and boil potatoes in salted water until tender. Drain well and mash until smooth.
In a skillet, melt 50g butter and sauté chopped onions until golden and caramelized, about 15 minutes.
Mix mashed potatoes, farmer's cheese, caramelized onions (reserve some for garnish), remaining 50g butter, salt, and pepper. Mix until well combined. Let cool.
Divide dough into 4 portions. Roll one portion thin (about 2mm) on floured surface. Keep other portions covered.
Cut circles using a glass or 3-inch cutter. Place tablespoon of filling in center of each circle.
Fold dough over filling to create half-moon shape. Press edges firmly to seal, then crimp with fingers or fork.
Bring large pot of salted water to boil. Boil pierogi in batches (don't overcrowd) until they float, then cook 2-3 minutes more.
Remove with slotted spoon. Serve immediately with melted butter, caramelized onions, sour cream, chives, and crispy bacon if using.
Alternatively, after boiling, pan-fry in butter until golden and crispy on both sides.

original.title: Ramen
original.description: A comforting Japanese noodle soup with a flavorful broth, noodles, soft-boiled eggs, and sliced pork.
instructions: Warm the broth in a pot and add soy sauce, grated ginger, and crushed garlic. Let it simmer for 10 minutes to deepen the flavor.
In a separate pot, cook the ramen noodles according to the package instructions, then drain well.
Prepare soft-boiled eggs by boiling them for 6 minutes, then cooling them in ice water and peeling carefully.
Add the cooked noodles to serving bowls and pour the hot broth over them.
Top each bowl with sliced pork, a soft-boiled egg cut in half, and chopped green onions.
Let the ingredients warm through for 1 minute before serving.

original.title: Ratatouille
original.description: A Provençal vegetable stew made with zucchini, eggplant, peppers, and tomatoes.
instructions: Heat olive oil in a pan, sauté onions and garlic 3-4 minutes.
Add eggplant, cook 5 minutes.
Add bell peppers and zucchini, cook 5 minutes.
Add tomatoes and herbs, simmer 20 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper, serve hot.

original.title: Seffa (Sweet Vermicelli with Cinnamon and Almonds)
original.description: A celebratory sweet couscous or vermicelli dish flavored with cinnamon, sugar, and butter, traditionally served at special occasions.
instructions: If using vermicelli, break into 2-inch pieces. If using couscous, place in a large bowl.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a large pan and toast vermicelli until golden (skip if using couscous).
Pour boiling water over vermicelli/couscous, add 1 tsp salt, and let sit covered for 10 minutes.
While grains hydrate, toast almonds in a dry pan until golden. Set aside.
Soak raisins in warm water with 1 tbsp orange blossom water for 15 minutes, then drain.
Fluff vermicelli/couscous with a fork, breaking up any lumps.
In a large steamer or couscoussier, steam the grains over boiling water for 20 minutes.
Return steamed grains to large bowl and mix in 100g melted butter, remaining orange blossom water, and sugar. Mix gently with forks.
Steam again for another 15 minutes until very fluffy.
To serve: Mound the seffa on a large platter. Make decorative patterns with ground cinnamon on top.
Sprinkle with toasted almonds and drained raisins.
Dust with powdered sugar and drizzle with remaining melted butter.
Serve warm as a sweet main course or dessert.

original.title: Sernik (Polish Baked Cheesecake)
original.description: A rich, dense baked cheesecake made with farmer's cheese, featuring a delicate crumb and traditional flavor - the centerpiece of Polish holiday tables.
instructions: Preheat oven to 160°C (320°F). Grease 9-inch springform pan and line with parchment.
For crust: Mix crushed cookies, melted butter, and sugar. Press firmly into bottom of pan. Chill.
Press farmer's cheese through fine sieve or food mill twice for ultra-smooth texture.
In large bowl, beat softened butter with sugar and vanilla sugar until light and fluffy, about 5 minutes.
Add egg yolks one at a time, beating well after each. Mix in lemon zest, lemon juice, and vanilla.
Add sieved cheese in three additions, mixing until smooth after each.
Sift in potato starch and flour, mix until just combined.
In clean bowl with clean beaters, whip egg whites with salt until stiff peaks form.
Gently fold egg whites into cheese mixture in three additions, being careful not to deflate.
Pour batter over crust and smooth top. Tap pan gently to remove air bubbles.
Bake for 70-90 minutes until golden and set but still slightly wobbly in center.
Turn off oven, open door slightly, and let cheesecake cool completely in oven (about 2 hours).
Refrigerate overnight (minimum 8 hours) before serving.
Dust with powdered sugar or add lemon glaze and berries before serving.

original.title: Chicken Shawarma
original.description: Popular Syrian street food made of marinated grilled chicken served in a wrap with garlic sauce and vegetables.

Marinate for at least 1 hour (or overnight for best flavor).
Cook chicken in a pan or oven until browned.
Slice the cooked chicken thinly.
Assemble wraps with garlic sauce and vegetables.

original.title: Shepherd's Pie (Lamb-Free Version)
original.description: Savory cottage pie with vegetables and mashed potato topping.
instructions: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F).
Boil potatoes until soft, mash with milk and butter.
Cook minced beef with chopped onions, carrots, peas until meat is browned.
Season with salt and pepper.
Transfer meat mixture to baking dish, spread mashed potatoes on top.
Bake 20-25 minutes until golden.
Serve hot.

original.title: Songpyeon
original.description: Traditional Korean half-moon rice cakes steamed with pine needles during Chuseok and filled with sweet fillings.
instructions: Mix glutinous rice flour with hot water and knead until smooth.
Combine sesame seeds, sugar, and honey to make the sesame filling.
Shape dough into small balls, flatten, fill with sweet paste, then fold and seal.
Steam the rice cakes for 15–20 minutes, traditionally over pine needles.
Brush lightly with sesame oil before serving.

original.title: Spaghetti alla Bolognese
original.description: The authentic meat sauce from Bologna - a rich, slow-cooked ragù with multiple meats, vegetables, and milk, served with tagliatelle (not spaghetti in Bologna, but adapted here).
instructions: Heat olive oil in large heavy pot. Add pancetta and cook until fat renders.
Add finely chopped onion, carrot, and celery (soffritto). Cook over low heat for 15 minutes until soft but not browned.
Increase heat, add ground meats, breaking up with spoon. Cook until browned, about 10 minutes.
Add tomato paste and cook for 2 minutes until darkened. Add red wine, scraping bottom of pot.
Simmer until wine evaporates, about 5 minutes. Add milk and nutmeg, simmer until milk is absorbed.
Add bay leaves and enough beef broth to barely cover meat. Bring to simmer, then reduce heat to lowest setting.
Partially cover and simmer for 3-4 hours, stirring occasionally and adding broth if too dry. Sauce should be thick but moist.
Cook spaghetti in salted boiling water until al dente. Reserve 1 cup pasta water.
Add drained spaghetti to sauce with some pasta water. Toss vigorously over heat until emulsified.
Serve immediately with generous amount of Parmigiano-Reggiano grated over top.

original.title: Sushi Rolls
original.description: Classic Japanese sushi rolls made with seasoned rice, nori sheets, and fresh fillings such as cucumber, avocado, and salmon.
instructions: Rinse the sushi rice several times until the water runs clear, then cook it according to package instructions.
While the rice is still warm, mix it gently with rice vinegar, sugar, and salt to create seasoned sushi rice. Let it cool completely.
Lay a bamboo sushi mat on a flat surface and place a nori sheet on top, shiny side down.
Spread a thin, even layer of sushi rice over the nori, leaving a small border at the top edge free for sealing.
Place thin slices of cucumber, avocado, and fresh salmon horizontally across the bottom third of the rice.
Lift the edge of the bamboo mat and roll the sushi forward tightly, applying gentle pressure to shape a firm roll.
Wet the top edge of the nori to seal the roll, then remove it from the mat.
Slice the roll into even pieces using a sharp, wet knife and serve with soy sauce, wasabi, and pickled ginger.

original.title: Tempura
original.description: Light and crispy Japanese tempura made with shrimp and vegetables dipped in airy batter and deep-fried until golden.
instructions: Peel and devein the shrimp, keeping the tails intact. Cut the vegetables into thin, uniform slices for even frying.
In a bowl, lightly beat the egg and mix in the cold water. Add the flour gently and stir briefly, leaving some lumps to ensure a light batter.
Heat oil in a deep pan to 170–180°C.
Dip the shrimp and vegetables individually into the batter, ensuring they are lightly coated.
Fry a few pieces at a time until they turn light golden and crispy, about 2–3 minutes per batch.
Place them on a paper towel to drain excess oil before serving.

original.title: Tiramisu Classico
original.description: The ultimate Italian dessert - layers of coffee-soaked ladyfingers and whipped mascarpone cream, dusted with cocoa powder.
instructions: Brew strong espresso and let cool completely. Mix with Marsala wine and rum if using.
Separate eggs. Beat egg yolks with 100g sugar until pale, thick, and ribbon-like, about 5 minutes.
Add mascarpone to yolk mixture and beat until smooth. Mix in vanilla extract.
In clean bowl with clean beaters, whip egg whites with pinch of salt until soft peaks form.
In another bowl, whip heavy cream with remaining 20g sugar until medium peaks.
Gently fold whipped cream into mascarpone mixture, then fold in egg whites until just combined.
Quickly dip ladyfingers in coffee mixture (1-2 seconds per side) and arrange in single layer in 9x13 inch dish.
Spread half mascarpone cream over ladyfingers, smoothing top.
Create second layer of dipped ladyfingers, then remaining cream.
Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 6 hours, preferably overnight.
Before serving, sift cocoa powder generously over top and sprinkle with grated chocolate.
Use sharp knife dipped in hot water to cut clean portions.

Mascarpone cheese 500g Fresh eggs, separated 4 Granulated sugar 120g Ladyfinger cookies (savoiardi) 300g Strong espresso coffee, cooled 400ml Marsala wine 4 tbsp Dark rum or brandy (optional) 2 tbsp Unsweetened cocoa powder 3 tbsp Dark chocolate, grated 50g Vanilla extract 1 tsp Salt pinch Heavy cream (35%) 200ml Brew strong espresso and let cool completely. Mix with Marsala wine and rum if using. Separate eggs. Beat egg yolks with 100g sugar until pale, thick, and ribbon-like, about 5 minutes. Add mascarpone to yolk mixture and beat until smooth. Mix in vanilla extract. In clean bowl with clean beaters, whip egg whites with pinch of salt until soft peaks form. In another bowl, whip heavy cream with remaining 20g sugar until medium peaks. Gently fold whipped cream into mascarpone mixture, then fold in egg whites until just combined. Quickly dip ladyfingers in coffee mixture (1-2 seconds per side) and arrange in single layer in 9x13 inch dish. Spread half mascarpone cream over ladyfingers, smoothing top. Create second layer of dipped ladyfingers, then remaining cream. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 6 hours, preferably overnight. Before serving, sift cocoa powder generously over top and sprinkle with grated chocolate. Use sharp knife dipped in hot water to cut clean portions. dessert coffee mascarpone no-bake classic

original.title: Torta di Mele della Nonna
original.description: Grandma's rustic Italian apple cake - moist, lightly spiced, and packed with fresh apples in a simple buttery batter.
instructions: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Butter and flour a 9-inch springform pan.
Peel, core, and slice apples into 1/4-inch slices. Toss with lemon juice to prevent browning.
In a large bowl, cream softened butter and sugar until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes.
Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Mix in vanilla extract and lemon zest.
In separate bowl, whisk together flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt.
Alternately add flour mixture and milk to butter mixture, beginning and ending with flour. Mix until just combined.
Fold in two-thirds of the apple slices until evenly distributed.
Pour batter into prepared pan and smooth top. Arrange remaining apple slices in concentric circles on top.
Sprinkle sliced almonds over apples. Bake for 50-60 minutes until golden and toothpick comes out clean.
While cake bakes, warm apricot jam with 1 tbsp water. Strain if lumpy.
Let cake cool in pan for 15 minutes, then brush warm cake with apricot glaze.
Cool completely before dusting with powdered sugar. Serve at room temperature.

original.title: English Trifle

Add a layer of custard, then fruits.

Chill in refrigerator 1-2 hours before serving.

original.title: Tteokbokki
original.description: Spicy Korean street food made with chewy rice cakes simmered in a sweet and spicy gochujang-based sauce.
instructions: Combine water (or broth), gochujang, sugar, soy sauce, garlic, and gochugaru in a pan and bring to a simmer.
Add the rice cakes and cook for 8–10 minutes until soft and thickened.
Add sliced fish cakes and green onions and cook for 3 more minutes.
Finish with sesame oil and serve hot.

original.title: Zrazy Zawijane (Polish Beef Rolls)
original.description: Tender beef slices stuffed with bacon, pickles, and vegetables, simmered in a rich gravy with mushrooms - a classic Polish comfort dish.

ingredients.item: Beef top round or sirloin, sliced thin

instructions: Pound beef slices between plastic wrap until very thin (about 1/4 inch). Season both sides with salt and pepper.
Spread about 1 tsp mustard on each beef slice. Place one bacon slice, one pickle, some grated carrot and chopped onion on each.
Roll up tightly and secure with toothpicks or tie with kitchen twine. Dredge rolls in flour, shaking off excess.
Heat oil and butter in large Dutch oven. Brown zrazy on all sides, about 8-10 minutes total. Remove and set aside.
In same pot, add mushrooms and remaining onion. Cook until softened, about 8 minutes.
Sprinkle with 2 tbsp flour and cook for 1 minute. Gradually add red wine, scraping up browned bits.
Add beef broth, bay leaves, allspice, and peppercorns. Return zrazy to pot, bring to simmer.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 2-2.5 hours until beef is very tender, turning occasionally.
Remove zrazy to platter. Strain sauce if desired, or leave mushrooms in. Adjust seasoning.
If sauce is too thin, mix 2 tbsp flour with 4 tbsp water, whisk into sauce and simmer until thickened.
Remove toothpicks/string, return zrazy to sauce to warm through. Garnish with parsley.
Serve with mashed potatoes, boiled potatoes, or kasza (buckwheat).
